title: التَّرْخِيم
description: Learn about التَّرْخِيم, the practice of dropping letters from the end of a name in the vocative for affection or ease: يَا فَاطِمُ (from فَاطِمَة)، يَا حَارِ (from حَارِث).

notes.title: What is التَّرْخِيم?
content: التَّرْخِيم is the practice of shortening a name in the vocative by dropping one or more letters from its end. It is used to express affection, tenderness, or simply for ease of pronunciation.
The word comes from the root رَخُمَ meaning 'to be soft/gentle.' When we use ترخيم, we're softening the name, often showing endearment.
keyPoints: حذف حرف أو أكثر من آخر الاسم

notes.title: Conditions for التَّرْخِيم
content: Not every name can undergo ترخيم. The name must meet certain conditions: it should be a proper noun (عَلَم), have more than three letters, and be in the vocative case.
Names ending in تاء التأنيث (ة) are the most common candidates. Names like فَاطِمَة، عَائِشَة، حَمْزَة undergo ترخيم by dropping the ة.
keyPoints: Must be a proper noun (عَلَم) or described noun
Names with تاء التأنيث: just drop ة

notes.title: Two Methods of التَّرْخِيم
content: After dropping the final letter(s), there are two schools of thought on how to treat the remaining form. These are called لُغَة مَنْ يَنْتَظِر and لُغَة مَنْ لَا يَنْتَظِر.
لغة من ينتظر: keep the original vowel on the new final letter (يَا حَارِ - keeping the kasra). لغة من لا ينتظر: put damma on the new final letter (يَا حَارُ).
keyPoints: لغة من ينتظر: keep original vowel (يَا فَاطِمِ or يَا حَارِ)
لغة من لا ينتظر: use damma (يَا فَاطِمُ or يَا حَارُ)
Both are acceptable in classical Arabic
The damma method (لا ينتظر) is more common

examples.arabic: يَا حَارِثُ → يَا حَارِ (ينتظر) / يَا حَارُ (لا ينتظر)
يَا مَالِكُ → يَا مَالِ / يَا مَالُ
يَا جَعْفَرُ → يَا جَعْفَ / يَا جَعْفُ
يَا مَنْصُورُ → يَا مَنْصُو / يَا مَنْصُ

notes.title: Classical Examples from Hadith and Poetry
content: التَّرْخِيم appears frequently in hadith literature. The Prophet (peace be upon him) addressed عائشة as يَا عَائِشُ showing affection. This is recorded in authentic hadiths.
Classical poetry also uses ترخيم extensively for metrical purposes and to express closeness or tenderness toward the one being addressed.
keyPoints: يَا عَائِشُ - from Prophet's hadith to Aishah
Shows intimacy and affection in address
Common in classical poetry for meter
